measure theory

Let μ\muμ be a Borel probability measure on R\RR and define f(t)=∫eitxdμ(x)f\p{t} = \int e^{itx} \diff\mu\p{x}f(t)=∫eitxdμ(x). Suppose that

lim⁡t→0f(0)−f(t)t2=0.\lim_{t\to0} \frac{f\p{0} - f\p{t}}{t^2} = 0.t→0lim​t2f(0)−f(t)​=0.

Show that μ\muμ is supported at {0}\set{0}{0}.
Solution.

Observe that by taking real parts,

Re⁡(f(0)−f(t)t2)=∫1−cos⁡txt2 dμ(x),\Re\p{\frac{f\p{0} - f\p{t}}{t^2}} = \int \frac{1 - \cos{tx}}{t^2} \,\diff\mu\p{x},Re(t2f(0)−f(t)​)=∫t21−costx​dμ(x),

Since cos⁡x≤1\cos{x} \leq 1cosx≤1 the integrand is non-negative, so by Fatou's lemma,

0=lim inf⁡t→0∫1−cos⁡txt2 dμ(x)≥∫lim inf⁡t→01−cos⁡txt2 dμ(x)=∫x22 dμ(x)=∫{x2>0}x22 dμ(x).\begin{aligned} 0 &= \liminf_{t\to0} \int \frac{1 - \cos{tx}}{t^2} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \\ &\geq \int \liminf_{t\to0} \frac{1 - \cos{tx}}{t^2} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \\ &= \int \frac{x^2}{2} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \\ &= \int_{\set{x^2 > 0}} \frac{x^2}{2} \,\diff\mu\p{x}. \end{aligned}0​=t→0liminf​∫t21−costx​dμ(x)≥∫t→0liminf​t21−costx​dμ(x)=∫2x2​dμ(x)=∫{x2>0}​2x2​dμ(x).​

Suppose μ\muμ were supported away from {0}\set{0}{0}. Since μ\muμ is Borel, this means that there exists a closed interval III not containing 000 such that μ(I)>0\mu\p{I} > 0μ(I)>0. Thus, x2≥δ>0x^2 \geq \delta > 0x2≥δ>0 for some δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 on III since x2x^2x2 is increasing, and so

0≥∫{x2>0}x22 dμ(x)≥∫Iδ2 dμ(x)=δμ(I)2>0,0 \geq \int_{\set{x^2 > 0}} \frac{x^2}{2} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \geq \int_I \frac{\delta}{2} \,\diff\mu\p{x} = \frac{\delta\mu\p{I}}{2} > 0,0≥∫{x2>0}​2x2​dμ(x)≥∫I​2δ​dμ(x)=2δμ(I)​>0,

which is impossible. Thus, μ\muμ must have been supported on {0}\set{0}{0} to begin with.
